much.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I’m feeling very much better, thank you.
Henry’s room is much bigger than mine.
These shoes are much more comfortable.
He was driving much too fast.
It’s much the best way to do it.
much.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: The adverb much is mainly used before comparative adjectives or adjectives with 'too'
He’s much older than she is
The soup was much too salty
It is not usually used before other adjectives, but much can be used before different, especially in negatives and questions
It's not much different from when I was young
much.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used to ask or talk about the degree of a difference
much.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: She kept weighing herself to see how much heavier she was getting.
much.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used to ask or talk about how big an additional amount of something is
much.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: How much longer do we have to wait?
much.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to emphasize the difference you are mentioning
much.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I was surprised to see how much better she was looking.
How much better life would be if we returned to the values of the past!
much.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: used to talk about a strong feeling or something that is done often
much.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: We’re looking forward to your visit so much.
You know how much I care about you.
I think you have to accept the pain, however much it hurts.
The money will buy much needed books for the school.
much.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I don’t have much money with me.
He didn’t say much about his trip.
Do you get much chance to travel in your job?
After much consideration we have finally arrived at a decision.
It was such a small thing to have caused so much trouble.
There was too much work for one person.
It would cost far too much to have the thing repaired.
Much of the city was destroyed in the attack.
much.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: used in negative expressions to say that something is not important, interesting, good etc
much.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I don’t think much of that idea  (=I do not think it is good).
The car may not be much to look at (=it does not look good) but it’s very reliable.
It’s the best book he’s written, but that’s not saying much (=none of his books is very good).
‘What are you doing?’ ‘Oh, not much, really.’
There’s nothing much we can do to help.
much.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0]: Much  is mainly used in questions and negative sentences, or after too or so
much.translation[1].note_box[0].items[1]: Much sounds very formal in positive statements It is usually better to say a lot of
There was a lot of food left
much.translation[1].note_box[0].items[2]: You use much before uncountable nouns
much.translation[1].note_box[0].items[3]: You use many before plural nouns
There are too many advertisements on TV
There are too much advertisements on TV
